text: But you got to take the average PM who lives in that land, all day, every day, and what they do is not in the Venn. I think those are people who are also performing customer centricity and performing user-centeredness a lot, when they're really not interested. And so this is not about researcher. This takes two sides. Fixing this broken system takes everyone, researchers, PMs, designers, everyone at a company, but also the way that organization is structured, and integrating itself in a different way. Everybody's got to come to the table.
speaker: Judd Antin
context: Lenny asks Judd about user-centered performance and what advice he'd give to PMs who might recognize themselves in this pattern. Judd explains that while researchers need to be more business-focused, the problem exists on both sides - many product managers also engage in performative customer-centricity without genuine interest in learning. He emphasizes that fixing the broken research system requires collaboration from all roles, not just researchers changing their approach.
text_ko: 근데 평균적인 PM(프로덕트 매니저)은 그런 영역에서 하루 종일 일하고, 그들이 하는 일은 벤 다이어그램(Venn diagram)의 겹치지 않는 부분에 있어요. 겉으로는 고객 중심성(customer centricity)이나 사용자 중심성(user-centeredness)을 많이 실천하는 것처럼 보이지만, 사실은 별로 관심이 없을 때가 많아요. 이건 리서처(researcher)만의 문제가 아니에요. 이 깨진 시스템을 고치려면 양쪽의 노력이 필요하고, 리서처와 PM, 디자이너(designer), 회사의 모든 사람이 참여해야 해요. 조직 구조도 달라져야 하고, 서로 다른 방식으로 통합되어야 해요. 결국 모두가 함께 나와서 참여해야 해요.
text_zh: 但你得看看那些天天泡在这个圈子里的普通PM(产品经理)，他们做的事情其实根本不在这个交集里。我觉得这些人也在装模作样地搞什么以客户为中心、以用户为中心那一套，但其实他们压根就不感兴趣。所以这不光是研究员的问题，这事儿得两方面一起来。要想修复这套坏掉的系统，需要所有人一起努力——研究员、PM、设计师，公司里的每个人都得参与，而且整个组织架构也得调整，用不同的方式整合在一起。大家都得坐到谈判桌前。
text_es: Pero hay que considerar al PM promedio que vive en ese mundo todo el día, todos los días, y lo que hace no está en ese diagrama de Venn. Creo que esa gente también anda diciendo que se enfoca en el cliente y que pone al usuario primero, pero en realidad no les interesa para nada. Y esto no es solo cosa del investigador. Esto tiene dos caras. Arreglar este sistema roto requiere que todos se involucren - investigadores, PMs, diseñadores, toda la empresa - pero también cambiar la estructura organizacional e integrar todo de manera diferente. Todos tienen que poner de su parte.

text: User-centered performance refers to customer obsession or user-centered practice that is symbolic rather than focused on learning. It's hugely common, I would argue. It's work we do to signal to each other how customer obsessed we are, not because we want to make a different decision. If your listeners are like, 'I don't do that.' I'm like, 'Think about it for a second. This is extremely common.' Every time a PM comes to a researcher at the end of a product process and says, 'Can you just run a quick user study just to validate our assumptions,' that's user-centered performance. It's too late to matter. We got to ship it. What they want is to check the box.
speaker: Judd Antin
context: At the opening of the podcast, Judd defines his concept of 'user-centered performance' - a phenomenon where teams go through the motions of being customer-obsessed without actually wanting to learn or change their decisions. He explains this is extremely common in product development, giving the example of PMs asking for validation studies at the end of product development when it's too late to actually incorporate findings.
text_ko: 사용자 중심 성과(user-centered performance)는 고객에 대한 집착이나 사용자 중심의 관행을 의미하는데, 학습에 집중하기보다는 상징적인 경우가 많아요. 사실 이건 굉장히 흔한 현상이라고 생각해요. 우리가 서로에게 고객에 대한 집착이 얼마나 강한지를 보여주기 위해 하는 일이지, 다른 결정을 내리기 위해서가 아니거든요. 만약 여러분이 '나는 그런 거 안 해요.'라고 생각한다면, 잠깐 생각해보세요. 이건 정말 흔한 일이에요. 제품 과정이 끝날 무렵에 PM이 연구자에게 와서 '우리의 가정을 검증하기 위해 간단한 사용자 조사를 해줄 수 있어요?'라고 말하는 경우가 바로 사용자 중심 성과예요. 그때는 이미 늦었고, 우리는 제품을 출시해야 하니까요. 그들이 원하는 건 체크박스를 채우는 거예요.
text_zh: 以用户为中心的表演(user-centered performance)指的是那种象征性的客户至上或以用户为中心的做法，而不是真正专注于学习。我觉得这种情况特别普遍。我们做这些工作是为了向彼此展示我们有多重视客户，而不是因为我们真的想做出不同的决策。如果你们听众觉得"我不会这样做"，我想说"仔细想想，这真的非常常见。"每次产品经理在产品流程快结束的时候跑去找研究员说"你能不能快速做个用户研究，验证一下我们的假设"，这就是以用户为中心的表演。这时候已经太晚了，起不了什么作用。产品必须得上线了。他们要的只是走个过场。
text_es: El rendimiento centrado en el usuario se refiere a esa obsesión por el cliente o esas prácticas que dicen ser centradas en el usuario pero que en realidad son más simbólicas que enfocadas en aprender de verdad. Yo diría que es súper común. Es trabajo que hacemos para demostrarles a los demás lo obsesionados que estamos con el cliente, no porque realmente queramos tomar una decisión diferente. Si los que me escuchan piensan "yo no hago eso", les digo "piénsenlo un segundo. Esto es extremadamente común". Cada vez que un PM se acerca a un investigador al final del proceso de producto y le dice "¿puedes hacer un estudio rápido de usuarios para validar nuestras suposiciones?", eso es rendimiento centrado en el usuario (user-centered performance). Ya es muy tarde para que importe. Tenemos que lanzar el producto. Lo que quieren es tachar la casilla.

text: One of my big mantras was, 'We don't validate, we falsify. We are looking to be wrong.' That is the mindset you should use when you're approaching insights and research. 'I want to be wrong. I want you to do research that shows we were off base in the following ways. Tell me exactly how and why in a way that allows me to fix it quickly.' But many PMs, many designers are not in that place. They do not want to be wrong. They're looking to validate. And that's user-centered performance.
speaker: Judd Antin
context: Judd explains his philosophy about the proper mindset for conducting user research. He argues that effective research should aim to prove assumptions wrong rather than validate existing beliefs. This contrasts with user-centered performance, where teams conduct research seeking confirmation of decisions they've already made, rather than genuinely wanting to learn and potentially change course based on findings.
text_ko: 제 큰 모토 중 하나는 "우리는 검증하는 게 아니라 반증해요. 우리는 틀리길 원해요."예요. 인사이트와 리서치에 접근할 때 그런 마음가짐을 가져야 해요. "내가 틀리길 바라요. 여러분이 우리가 다음과 같은 방식으로 빗나갔다는 걸 보여주는 리서치를 해주세요. 빠르게 고칠 수 있도록, 정확히 어떻게 그리고 왜 틀렸는지 알려주세요." 그런데 많은 제품 관리자들(PMs)과 디자이너들(designers)은 그런 태도가 아니에요. 틀리길 원하지 않아요. 검증하려고 하죠. 그리고 그게 바로 사용자 중심 성과(user-centered performance)에 머무르는 태도예요.
text_zh: 我一直坚持一个理念："我们不是为了验证，而是为了证伪。我们就是要找出自己哪里错了。" 这就是你做洞察和研究时应该有的心态。"我希望自己是错的。我希望你们做的研究能指出我们在哪些地方搞偏了。告诉我具体怎么偏了，为什么偏了，让我能快速调整过来。" 但很多产品经理(PM)、很多设计师都做不到这一点。他们不想承认自己错了，总想着去验证自己的想法。这其实是在做样子给用户看。
text_es: Una de mis frases favoritas era: "No validamos, falsificamos. Buscamos estar equivocados." Esa es la mentalidad que deberías tener cuando te acercas a los insights y la investigación. "Quiero estar equivocado. Quiero que hagas investigación que demuestre que estábamos totalmente fuera de lugar y de qué maneras. Dime exactamente cómo y por qué, de una forma que me permita arreglarlo rápido." Pero muchos PMs, muchos diseñadores no están en esa onda. No quieren estar equivocados. Buscan validar. Y eso es teatro centrado en el usuario.

text: There's a vicious cycle that's been happening, is from where I sit, and this is what I hear from many, many researchers and research leaders, which is a lot of companies hired a lot of researchers with great intentions, didn't quite know how to integrate them. And UX research is a newer discipline, so maybe that's not surprising. We're still learning how to use it. 'Cool, let's evolve.' But a lot of companies hired these people, but they hired them into kind of like a service discipline, very reactive, not in the room, not integrated in the way I said.
speaker: Judd Antin
context: Lenny asks why research should be more integrated when it seems like research has been less helpful than expected. Judd explains the vicious cycle where companies hired researchers during the ZIRP era with good intentions but positioned them as a service function rather than strategic partners. This reactive positioning prevents researchers from having input on the right questions to ask and building direct relationships with product teams.
text_ko: 제가 보기엔 계속 악순환이 일어나고 있어요. 많은 연구자들과 리서치 리더들에게서 들은 건데, 많은 회사가 좋은 의도로 연구자들을 많이 채용했지만 이들을 조직에 어떻게 녹여야 할지 잘 몰랐어요. UX 리서치(UX research)는 비교적 새로운 분야라서 그리 놀랍진 않아요. 아직 어떻게 활용할지 배우는 중이고, ‘좋네, 진화하자’ 하는 단계예요. 그런데 많은 회사가 이 사람들을 뽑긴 했지만 서비스를 제공하는 역할처럼, 말하자면 서비스형 역할(service discipline)로 채용해서 매우 반응형(reactive)이고 회의나 의사결정 자리에도 함께 있지 않고 제가 말한 방식대로 통합되지 않았어요.
text_zh: 从我的角度看，现在有个恶性循环在发生，我从很多很多研究员和研究团队负责人那里都听到这样的情况：很多公司当初是好心招了一堆研究员，但其实不太知道怎么把他们融入进来。UX研究(UX research)本来就是个比较新的领域，所以这样也不奇怪。我们都还在摸索怎么用好它。"行吧，那就慢慢发展呗。"但是很多公司虽然招了这些人，却把他们当成了服务性岗位，很被动，不让他们参与核心讨论，也没有像我刚才说的那样真正整合进去。
text_es: Hay un círculo vicioso que está pasando, desde mi perspectiva, y esto es lo que escucho de muchísimos investigadores y líderes de investigación: muchas empresas contrataron a montones de investigadores con muy buenas intenciones, pero no tenían ni idea de cómo integrarlos. Y la investigación UX es una disciplina bastante nueva, así que tal vez no sorprende tanto. Todavía estamos aprendiendo cómo usarla. "Bueno, vamos evolucionando." Pero muchas empresas contrataron a esta gente, pero los metieron como en una disciplina de servicio, súper reactiva, sin estar en las reuniones importantes, sin estar integrados de la manera que te digo.

text: The multimillion dollar button. And basically we did research which revealed that people weren't going down the purchase funnel because they were afraid. The calls to actions on the button was making them afraid that it would initiate a purchase when really it was just taking the next step. We changed the text on the button with help from our amazing content design, our UX writing team. We basically changed seven characters and made Airbnb millions of dollars, because what we found out was really simple. It was just like, 'Hey, this button feels scary. The CTA on the button feels scary.'
speaker: Judd Antin
context: Judd shares a famous example from Airbnb to illustrate how micro-level research can deliver massive business value quickly. When explaining that good research can be fast rather than slow, he describes how his team discovered through rapid user research that a button's call-to-action text was scaring users away from proceeding in the booking funnel, thinking it would immediately charge them when it was just the next step.
text_ko: 이건 수백만 달러를 만들어낸 버튼 얘기예요. 사실 조사해보니 사람들이 구매 퍼널(purchase funnel)을 끝까지 진행하지 않는 이유가 두려움 때문이었어요. 버튼에 적힌 콜 투 액션(CTA) 문구 때문에 누르면 바로 결제가 시작될까 봐 겁을 먹고 있었던 거죠. 실제로는 단지 다음 단계로 넘어가는 것뿐이었는데요. 그래서 우리의 훌륭한 콘텐츠 디자인(content design)과 UX 라이팅(UX writing) 팀의 도움으로 버튼 문구를 바꿨어요. 문자 7자만 바꿨는데 에어비앤비에 수백만 달러를 안겨줬어요. 우리가 알아낸 건 정말 단순했어요 — 사람들이 “이 버튼이 무서워요, 버튼의 콜 투 액션(CTA) 문구가 무섭게 느껴져요”라고 느끼고 있었던 거예요.
text_zh: 价值几百万美元的按钮。我们做了调研发现，用户在购买漏斗(purchase funnel)里走不下去，就是因为害怕。按钮上的行动召唤(call to action)让他们以为一点就会直接下单，其实只是进入下一步而已。后来我们和超棒的内容设计团队、用户体验写作(UX writing)团队一起，把按钮上的文字改了改。就改了七个字符，就给爱彼迎赚了几百万美元。因为我们发现的道理特别简单，就是"哎，这个按钮让人觉得可怕，按钮上的CTA让人害怕"。
text_es: El botón de varios millones de dólares. Básicamente hicimos una investigación que reveló que la gente no avanzaba en el embudo de compra (purchase funnel) porque tenía miedo. Las llamadas a la acción (calls to action) del botón les daba miedo porque pensaban que iba a procesar la compra cuando en realidad solo era para dar el siguiente paso. Cambiamos el texto del botón con ayuda de nuestro increíble equipo de diseño de contenido y redacción UX. Básicamente cambiamos siete caracteres y le hicimos ganar millones de dólares a Airbnb, porque lo que descubrimos era súper sencillo. Era como, 'Oye, este botón da miedo. El CTA del botón da miedo.'

text: NPS is the best example of the marketing industry marketing itself. And the problem is this threatens many people's livelihoods, because there's an entire industry of consultants and software providers that want you to believe NPS is a useful and accurate metric. The problem is, the consensus in the survey science community is that NPS makes all the mistakes. So it's a garbage in, garbage out problem.
speaker: Judd Antin
context: Lenny asks about Judd's strong opinions on NPS (Net Promoter Score). Judd argues that NPS is fundamentally flawed from a survey science perspective, despite being widely promoted by consultants and software companies. He explains that the survey science community recognizes NPS as methodologically unsound, making it an unreliable metric for measuring customer satisfaction and loyalty.
text_ko: NPS(넷 프로모터 스코어)는 마케팅 업계가 자기 업계를 홍보하는 가장 좋은 사례예요. 문제는 이게 많은 사람들의 생계를 위협한다는 거예요. 컨설턴트와 소프트웨어 제공업체들로 이루어진 거대한 산업이 NPS가 유용하고 정확한 지표라고 믿게 만들고 싶어하거든요. 그런데 설문조사 과학(survey science) 쪽의 합의는 NPS가 온갖 실수를 다 저지른다는 거예요. 결국엔 입력이 엉망이면 출력도 엉망인 문제(garbage in, garbage out)가 되는 셈이에요.
text_zh: NPS就是营销行业给自己做营销的最佳例子。问题在于这威胁到了很多人的饭碗，因为有一大堆咨询师和软件供应商都指着让你相信NPS是个有用又准确的指标吃饭。但问题是，调研科学界的共识是NPS犯了所有不该犯的错误。所以这就是典型的垃圾进垃圾出(garbage in, garbage out)的问题。
text_es: El NPS es el mejor ejemplo de cómo la industria del marketing se vende a sí misma. Y el problema es que esto amenaza el sustento de mucha gente, porque hay toda una industria de consultores y proveedores de software que quieren que creas que el NPS es una métrica útil y precisa. El problema es que el consenso en la comunidad de ciencias de encuestas es que el NPS comete todos los errores posibles. O sea, es un problema de "basura entra, basura sale" (garbage in, garbage out).
